reviewText: Nostalgic convenience.  Certainly brings back a lot of the fun of 16-bit RPGs, but includes a lot of nice additions that many of those older games did not such as being able to save anywhere at any time, conveniently placed restore points (especially before boss battles), ability to one-up" if you die and want to try a battle again
recommended: able to warp to any town at pretty much anytime (even from dungeons)
hoursPlayed: limited number of random encounters
voteText:
and a run button.  I wish all those older games had these features as it pobably would have saved my parents from yelling at me to hurry up as I'm trying to fight my way back to an inn just to save my progress.

CSTW is really geared towards the fun aspect of these older RPGs.  Combat is overall simplistic and I found myself settling in on the same attacks over and over.  This may turn off some players but I didn't mind it too much.  There are some attacks and "team-up" attacks that I did not use at all or maybe once.

Some parts of the game aren't explained very well such as the "insanity" mode that some attacks will cause.  When I used it
helpfulPercent: the monsters caused more damage
votesHelpful: but also took more damage from player attacks.  Apparently this mode can also unlock special attacks from certain monsters.  The monster's picture will also change slightly to show that it is "insane".\n\nThere were a couple of nit-picky items that did not affect gameplay a whole lot but I thought were a little annoying.  First of all
votesTotal: the animations during the battles was very minimal.  The monsters did not move and only flashed when hit.  You can see your character's attacks in the form of a swipe or some kind of spell effect
votesFunny: but that was about it.  Also
commentsCount: some indicators on character status during fights would have been nice to show if they were poisoned
column16: stunned
column17: etc.  The game will tell you in the text box if a character's status is impacted
column18: but its so easy to just click past these messages from habit that its easy to miss.\n\nOverall this is a good game that took up about 20 hours of my time.  There were still some optional dungeons to complete and I may still do those.  If you like old-school RPGs or want to take a break with something more casual
column19: then I would recommend this game to scratch that itch.  Plus you can get it on sale for less coin than what you probably have clinking around in your car's cup-holder."

reviewText:
This game is a gem for those that are looking to play as the elder god and somehow save the world. The games positives are the silliness and gameplay. Also, if you are into retro graphics then you will like this.

The cons are if you do not defeat your opponent fast enough they will quickly become too powerful for you to be able to do much against them. Also, the fact that you can play as cthulhu which wouldn't be possible as it is a concept that merely thinking about it causes insanity.

This game is for those that want to play an RPG that doesn't take itsself seriously.

reviewText:
Despite the fact that I am a Cthulhu Mythos fanatic and a great enthusiast of the RPG genre (including cRPG) I have found this game bringing moderate fun only.
The story is tries to be witty and humorous but achieves this goal only a few times during the game. The jokes are usually poor, the whole concept of character knowing he is a part of game/movie/novel/etc. has been used for too many times already. Jokes in the names or descriptions of monster remind me of high school times - in this case it's not a 'pro' feature.
The characters are plain and one dimensional.
The world of the game is absurd, not necessarily in a good way. It's a mix of Cthulhu Mythos and fantasy worlds (with goblins etc.), there is a concept of insanity, but other than that the mechanics of the fight and magic is D&D-like - nothing really specific for the CoC.
The gameplay is very simple - you walk, find loot, fight in all too many random encounters (which are tiring, not bringing any fun). The dungeons are boring and involve lots of walking (probably so that there is enough time to fill the game with random encounters), There are some puzzles, but the main puzzle is to find yourself around in these mazes (thank devs for the 'run; mode).
Battles with bosses require some thinking and are interesting.
Music is decent, but too repetitive.

So why the 'thumb up'? As I've said earlier, I'm a fanatic, so if they made a Tic-tac-toe and named it 'Cthulhu Riddle' I'd probably recommend it.

Also keep in mind that this game comes in a package with 'Breath of Death VII'. From what I have senn both games are very very similar, so there is really no need to choose the lesser evil.

Ia R'lyeh.

reviewText:
This game offers very little besides the wacky title.

What passes for a story is Cthulhu going around doing heroic things in his own way, which is sometimes something funny like saving innocent zombies from the thing controlling them but mostly things like returning a lost dog or healing an illness  by finding magic water.

There is very little cast development, the characters stay mostly one dimensional and while the character concepts like a talking sword or an alien cat might seem interesting at first, very little is done with them.

The music is nothing worth remembering, not even the final boss theme was that catchy.

The dungeon design is bad, the only puzzles are barriers that can be opened with a button press and a falling/rising water level. The levels are designed to make the player get lost, probably to extend the short playtime, if you want to find the right way, take the path that looks the least like it will lead to progress.

Of course, the graphics are also nothing noteworthy, they go for a retro" pixel style
date: but this is just an excuse for being lazy with the graphics since they are nowhere near actually good looking detailed pixel art like: http://i.imgur.com/buH9JjF.gif\n\nThe gameplay is one good aspect
recommended: you are often in danger of dying and all of your HP get's refreshed after each fight
hoursPlayed: even if a party member dies
voteText: thus making even a victory with only one fighter left standing worth it. The only thing to look out for between fights is the MP count
helpfulPercent: since it isn't completely replenished. This game also makes buffs and debuffs useful
votesHelpful: even in non boss fights. You still have a lot of skills you rarely or never use though. The danger of loosing is sadly undermined by being able to save anywhere
votesTotal: although this might not be the case on harder difficulties.\n\nLike any jrpg though
votesFunny: fighting get's tedious after some time and since there is little else worth looking at in this title
commentsCount: I suggest you avoid it."

reviewText: This game got pretty good ratings in international reviews by both players and professionals. I like the Lovecraftian mythos, I like SNES style RPGs and I don't care whether it's indie or how good the graphics are, when the gameplay works. Therefore, I bought this game with some expectations. You certainly guessed it already: This game sucks hard! Or to be a bit more diplomatic: I really don't understand what's so great about this game. Sure, the idea is funny and maybe the story is interesting. But that's it! The combat is boring, tedious and repetitive. All you do the whole game is follow the linear story path, talk a little and fight. Oh, and there is the fighting. Did I mention that? Combat takes like 95% of the time, so it's really hard to get into any kind of story.\n\nDO NOT BUY THIS GAME!

reviewText: Thankfully this is a rather short RPG because I don't see how anyone could tolerate it much longer than that. Pretty much every dungeon is exactly the same, big sprawling maze with random encounters and the occasional chest. The hardest thing about the game is finding the next level of the dungeon, really. Mobs generally aren't too tough and it's easy to be overpowered in this game. The bosses are kind of a joke; even the final boss took practically no effort at all. The story kind of stops caring about a quarter of the way through the game and there's no sense of atmosphere at all. It's not even that f funny, either. There's some jokes but they're far too infrequent for it to really be a comedy game. The last dungeon has a big difficulty spike which is a bit unwarranted but even then, hopping into an optional dungeon and then back into the last dungeon basically destroyed all the challenge I was having. It's just... bland. I don't like RPGs in general and only got this in a bundle, and it was short enough for me to not get bored of it, at least. I wouldn't call it bad" for what it is
date: but I certainly can't say it blew me away or anything."

Starts off pretty charming and funny, but then quickly becomes one-dimensional and boring. The gameplay is typical RPGMaker style bland turn-based combat, and there isn't enough story or character to really carry you through the repetitive dungeons and encounters.

Not a bad price for the amount of content, but the content itself is thin and shallow.

reviewText:
Gameplay's pretty much equal comparing to Breath of Death VII, except with a new story and new additions such as the insanity system. Both games come in a bundle and, if caught on sale, can be bought for ridiculous prices.

Pros:
- Catchy soundtrack!
- Tribute to the 16-bit era, plus a comical side;
- Hero Cthulhu!
- Insanity system is a great plus!
- Sprites are well designed and make for some good battle scenery;
- A demonstration that a good game doesn't need great graphics to be fun!

Cons:
- If you don't like 16-bit games, stay out of this one. Kind of stupid not to like them anyways.

reviewText: I'm a big fan of JRPGS, however, since nowadays I'm a PC gamer, it's hard to find traditonal JRPGS. Cthulhu Saves the World is one of the few on Steam, and it's great. The price is stupidly low (it's like 3$ for two games), and you'll easily get 6 or more hours out of it. The game plays like an old Dragon Quest or Final Fantasy. You traverse an overworld, find towns, dungeons, etc, etc. The game itself is fairly linear, with a couple of side dungeons spread over the world. What makes the game unique in mind is the battle system. While it may look like nothing special, it's actually quite unique. Each turn that goes by the enemies all have their attack increased by 10%, what this means is that you'll quickly be overwhelmed. This means you have to stratgeize how to defeat the monsters in the quickest way possible. You won't be mashing 'attack' throughout the battles in this game. Dungeons can often be really maze like, which is a pain, but it's not a major problem.

reviewText:
SNES-esque RPG starring H.P. Lovecraft's famous monster, Cthulhu. There's a lot I don't like about RPGs in general, but this one manages to correct a lot of the most frustrating aspects of other RPGs:

-Allies are fully healed after battles, rather than leaving you barely limping along only to be killed in the next random encounter. (Battles are still quite hard though! MP is not fully restored after each battle, so use it wisely.)
-Only a limited number of random encounters will occur in each area before they are turned off." You have the option to manually begin a battle with monsters if you still want to fight in a "finished" area.
-You can save any time
date: anywhere! (Outside of battles of course.)\n\nGood humor
hoursPlayed: and a bizarre plot that manages to make sense despite how odd it is. You won't find much that's better for the $3.00 price tag (and that $3 also includes Breath of Death VII
voteText: another RPG from the same company - this game is basically $1.50!)."

reviewText:
Cthulhu Saves the World is a game that plays and feels like Final Fantasy Mystical Quest. Well, except that it brings its own innovations to the table - the Unite attacks (which are awesome) and the round-based combat system (which pretty much limits the amount of turns you have to defeat your enemies). You'd expect a bland plot and forced humor; this is not the case. It's an amazing game with surprising depth in the gameplay; not just a tribute to the old JRPG games but a good game on its own - something the guys at Ubisoft should take note of when making something like Child of Light, a game that looked fantastic yet lacked in every other department.

Limiting the amount of random encounters (after some fights they become optional) reduces the padding combat that plagued early Final Fantasy games.

Another unexpected strong point is the soundtrack - a mix of JRPG-inspired 8-bit tunes with 80s heavy metal sounds just epic.

I definitely recommend this game to every fan of the classic JRPG genre and Lovecraft mythos who also likes to have a good laugh. Well done, Zeboyd Games, well done indeed. Luckinly, I also have Breath of Death VII in my library to play after I finish this one. But I'll watch out for your other games and new releases too.

reviewText:
So, in hypocritical style, after recommending Breath of Death as a fun, satirical take on classic RPGs, I am NOT recommending Cthulhu Saves the World.

Wouldn't a game whose premise involves the lord of annihilation and suffering plunged into the role of saving the world be worth a token recommendation because of its novel story line?" I can hear folks asking me. "Wouldn't a game by the same developers as Breath of Death be similar?"


And the answer is a resounding 'YES' to both. Both games are nearly identical when it comes to level design
recommended:
combat mechanics and funny/corny dialogue. I think the only difference is me - I'm clearly suffering from some sort of comedy RPG overload.

reviewText:
AUDIO: Stock                                                      AESTHETIC: Retro
MEMORABILITY: Nightmareish                          WORTH: LOL

PROS: Writing an anti-hero is a bold choice. (Too bad it failed.) Battling itself is not that bad, takes an Earthboundish sort of approach. Overworld graphics are tolerable.

CONS: I'm shocked to see how many people are praising it for its humor and story, and then I remember the current state of the film industry. I could not tolerate any text that popped up in Cthulhu Saves the World; It is the 9gag of video games. The dialogue is complete and utter trash. I've never been subjected to a more hideous form of unfunny. Every line of garbage uttered by the protagonist and the insufferable mary-sues following him made me writhe in discomfort.

OVERALL: My health issues coincidentally took a turn for the worse around the time I bought this game. It would not surprise me at all if this game was so unfunny that it actually, literally gave me cancer. Direct exposure to it was like being viciously irradiated.

SCORE: 1/10

reviewText:
This game is for all classic RPG lovers.

This game is as simple as brilliant. You find yourself as the mighty Cthulhu, weakend by a strange magic, seeking for glory and honor to get your powers back.

Can you rescue the land from the ultimate devil?

All in all its fun to read the dialogues of the characters and to drive the story forward.

The combat can be challenging if you are tired and just want to smash some random buttons, so be carefull.

For the hardcore gamers there are some fine brutal modes which can make your playthrough to a pure mess. Good luck dealing with them!

The playtime is around 10 hours depending on how much you explore.

reviewText:
First of all, I have to admit this is my very first time playing something like this, and I found out it's not my cup of tea. So if you're into retro 2D RPG games, this review won't be to your liking either.

Gameplay is pretty simple and the story does show a lot of fun. However, battles are overly simplistic and get rather repetitive pretty quickly. Story wise it's not very interesting. There is some funny interaction between the characters but I get the feeling it's merely the required minimum. The game is praised for it's humor. Let's get this straight: it's not hilarious. I didn't laugh, I didn't even snicker. It's just amusing. That's all. And not good enough to keep my attention/interest after the battles failed to do that as well. I guess it's similar to the situation when one types LOL" constantly without really "Laughing Out Loud".

Bottom line.
If you're not into retro 2D RPGs you'll get bored. If you're into retro 2D RPGs maybe
date: just maybe and if you have pretty low expectations from a cheap game."

reviewText:
Time of completion:: 6 hours and 3 minutes
Date of writing the review: 04.March.2015
Difficulty I played at: Easy
My YouTube channel:   link
My rating: 5/10
===========================
I want to start off by saying that never before this game have I played any sort of top-down game, let alone a top-down (old-school) RPG like this one, so I hold no nostalgia factor for games like this one. This is from the perspective of a man who has been PC gaming since 2002 (was 10 y/o) and is just introduced to this type of RPGs.

It's very difficult to give a good game a downvote, but even if everything else is done great, if your main mechanic (the combat) is done poorly, then the game loses all it's value and becomes bad and frustrating.

Let's begin with the praises first:

As I mentioned, most aspects of the game are done great, we will start off with the:

VisualsThe art for the characters is great, when you see emotion, the picture changes according to the mood of the character. There is lots of variety between most of the monsters and you don't feel like fighting a different version of the same creature over and over again, even through some are just re-skinned and re-colored.

SoundGreat ! Music is awesome and the sound effects while fighting vary from each-other.

StoryAgain, great ! I love how you are a hero, but also not. You want to be evil, but you have to do good things in order to be able to do bad things. I know, right ? Mind=blown. The ending is very disappointing though, I really hoped that the opposite of what happened to happen.

ControlsOh thank you, thank you, thank you for adding a sprint button, also thank you for making the attack" command to be the default one. That helps with spamming ENTER in order to get out of the garbage fighting system as fast as possible.

...and now the bad...

LengthI wish it wasn't this long honestly. Every dungeon frustrated me and I blitzed though it as fast as possible. I am so glad I chose the easy difficulty
date: otherwise I had to spend a lot more time planning my moves and forget where I was going by the time the fight is over.\n\nThe other and most annoying thing is how the combat worksWhenever you are in a dungeon (or outside one
recommended: doesn't matter) you will constantly get interrupted by random encounters. For some it's possible to spam the ENTER key in order to pass them fastly
hoursPlayed: but for the later ones that option goes down the drain.\n\nPicture this: I am happily strolling down a dungeon
voteText: thinking of how to reach the end
helpfulPercent: I see the layout and think of the best path to take.... and all of a sudden.... BAM! A RANDOM ENCOUNTER. These things can take 5+ minutes. You have to concentrate
votesHelpful: think of your best powers to use
votesTotal: look at your MP
commentsCount: look at the monsters' stats and so on. You get so involved it the fight that when you finish
column16: you completely forgot where the hell you were going and forgot your plan completely.\n\nSo you set off again
column18: find the way and BAM! AGAIN A RANDOM ENCOUNTER. This repeats 30 times
column19: making you walk the same path 30 times
column20: seeing the same thing over and over and over(x27) again. This is not fun
column21: it completely ruined the game for me. Exploration is out of the question in this game. I cannot enjoy the look of the dungeon even
column22: if the gameplay constantly gets interrupted by random encounters.\n\nThat is why I don't recommend the game and I am sorry I bought it (only for 31 cents
column23: but even free I wouldn't have played it if I knew how bad it was). It's a shame really because the game does everything else fine."

reviewText:
Cthulhu Saves the World is an interesting game.

On the outside it looks like a simple turn-based rpg trying to copy classic rpgs like Dragon Quest, but with much more cheesier and non-proffesional graphics.

But this game is a gem. On the inside it all comes together to make a very entertaining game.

It has several innovations: Everytime your character levels you get to choose the improvement the character gets, you can only fight a certain amount of monsters in an area before you stop randomly encounter any more(with a option to keep fighting if you want), you get combo points for hitting enemies over time which you can then use on special moves to do large amounts of damage which when combined with the fact enemies get stronger every turn means each battle goes by pretty fast.

Long story short, if you like old rpg games like Dragon Quest or Final Fantasy then this is a good buy, especially with the cheap price and being bundled with a similar game.

reviewText:
Both of these games uses the battle displays from ancient rpgs, think Earthbound, Shin Megami Tensei, or a numbered Phantasy Star (not online, the original games).

Both of them rely on pretty decent jokes, although Cthulhu, being the second game they made, takes the ham way higher, and as a result is mostly funnier. Even though you never see your charathers in the battle, its still pretty involving, with stat buffs and debuffs as well as mana preservation, although it isn't quite as stressful as the games it's actually based on.

The game helps you along with some major streamlining, especially in the inventory and telling you where to go next, although you can sequence break if you are willing to overlevel a bit.

Although if this is the first time you've played one of these in a while, the game will probbably seem monstrously difficult, especially with its unique health refill feature giving them an excuse to use a set monster encounter rate.

In all honesty, I think you should use PSN, GoG, wiiware, xbox arcade,  ceirtain indie releases, a compilation game (I can think of several sega genesis sets that include three phantasy star games, not to mention other awesome things in other genres) to experience this sub-genre in pure form.

reviewText: this is very similar to Breath of Death but with a few new features- you can fly and teleport around the world and swap around which characters are active per fight.  They've also improved the graphics a little, but the story and characters just aren't as good as Breath of Death's.  Wandering around a quirkily rebuilt post-apocalyptic world with a girl ghost hopelessly enamored with a mute depressive skeleton was more fun than this game's cascade of pop horror/cat owner references and boring protagonist.\n\nAs with Breath of Death, there are a lottttt of pointless battles and exploring that are a pain to get through.  But my biggest gripe is that while Breath of Death's boss battles were fantastic and the one really enjoyable part of that game, Cthulhu's bosses are lame.  It's very easy to build one set of characters for disabling/aoes (for trash mobs) and another set for groups heals/combo builds (for bosses), which (at least on Medium) made every single fight in the game a breeze.

reviewText:
Nothing makes Lovecraft roll in his grave more than this game. I got it, expecting it to actually be clever, but soon found myself wallowing in misery and disappointment. It's supposed to be humorous, but the humor boils down to making silly faces and putting Cthulhu into only mildly ridiculous situations. There's a bit of fourth wall humor, but it's far from adroit. In addition, his out of character reactions only left me cringing. This is a god who makes people insane just by being seen, but here we have him idly chatting with mermaids. It's not funny, it's a failure to draw comedy from an emasculated creature of pure destruction. It's saddening that the only way they could conceive of a Lovecraftian comedy was to completely change the very fabric of what the elder gods are. The only relation this game actually has to Lovecraft's works is in name alone. You could name all of the characters and places differently, it would still be the same game.

Gameply-wise, it's as bare bones as an RPG can get. There are no mechanics we haven't seen since the 80's. Every battle can be won by mashing the fight button, and there's a good chance you won't have to grind either. Some of the maps are too long, and the encounter rate will have you groaning over the tedium of having fought this same enemy fifty times in the past twenty minutes. I explored most (I say most because toward the end I just wanted to finish and be done with it) of this game's maps, and there are very few secrets to encounter. In fact, there's very little to the game besides the main quest. There's a few game modes to unlock, but I haven't bothered playing them because of how soul crushing the main game is.

If you're an appreciator of Lovecraft's work, or if you think comedy should be witty, or if you like innovative RPG mechanics, this is not the game for you. You're better off spending your money on a hamburger, at least it won't leave you starving and depressed.

reviewText:
Cthulhu Saves the World is an old-school JRPG, and by old school, I mean they ditch all modern innovations, ideas and sensibilities the have accumulated over the years. Which is the point, sure, but it just doesn't add up to much these days, unfortunately. The quirky humour occasionally hits its mark and the characters are, at first, a bit more interesting than the usual JRPG trope characters. However, there doesn't seem to be any more to them except the very superficial quirkiness.

Gameplay is the usual old-school JRPG stuff. That is grind. Lots of monotonous grind. In the most baffling design decision I've encountered in a while, your party is completely healed after a won battle, but your mana is not restored. It might not sound so bad, until you realise that without Techs and Magics, your party is consistently and constantly getting beaten. So now you either:

A) have to backtrack to a place where you can restore your mana or

B) win fights without using mana. Which is not happening, not after the first area or so.

Granted, the ability to save anywhere and start random fights almost anytime from the party meny are appreciated, but in the end you still feel like you are wasting your time. The jokes, characters and settings are interesting enough to hold your interest for an hour or two, but eventually the monotony of the gameplay and the frustration of the difficulty curve eat away at your enjoyment.

reviewText:
[Spoiler-Free Review]

The spiritual successor to Breath of Death VII, Cthulhu Saves the World turns it's parodial focus to Lovecraft's ultimate evil-doer and dares you to pull it's finger.

In addition to the much improved engine which brings the series more in line with it's 16-bit forefathers (bridges are now beautifully rendered), Cthulhu features a fleshed out campaign with an all-new cast of characters and plenty of post game bonus content for completionists everywhere. There's even a second quest with an all-new storyline once you've completed the first.

I'll admit I'm not very well-versed in Cthulhuian lore and felt the humour was a bit too forced and goofy at times as a result. Where Breath of Death was sharp and witty, Cthulhu was brazen, outlandish and downright silly. Like a teenager trying to impress his friends with useless and mundane skills".

The music is still unconventionally memorable (hard rock cave music?) and nods to Zeboyd's history are strewn throughout the game. As with the first game
date: the optional developer's commentary is enlightening and entertaining and fits perfectly within a game unafraid to break the fourth wall.\n\nCthulhu Saves the World is a bit of an enigma however
recommended: while I enjoyed it less than Breath of Death VII
hoursPlayed: I'm willing to admit it's probably more to do with my lack of understanding of the source material. I ended up playing this game nearly two times longer than I did Breath of Death VII and enjoyed most of it. Chances are if you've played the first game
voteText: you'll want to help Cthulhu Save the World too.\n\nUm... hurry?"

reviewText:
This is a fun, retro RPG that doesn't take itself too seriously.  However, it's not without problems.

The plot is quirky and the dialog full of one-liners and bad puns.  The game is strongest during dialogue, with back and forths between the main characters and the narrator.  There are also plenty of lines when examing bookshelves and chest of drawers that will make you chuckle too.

This game has great music (just had to make sure I mentioned that).

The main problem I had with this game was the random encounters on places that weren't the world map.  These areas are giant labyrinths and you end up wandering around, lost, while getting pestered with battles.  After a while, you're strong enough that there's no great risk to these battles (although to be fair, I only played on Normal difficulty so other ones might be better in this regard) so you end up sighing, mashing Return and waiting for the damned battle to finish.

A few hours into the game, I ended up working around the too frequent random battles by going to the start of each new area and selecting 'Fight' from the menu (which forces a new random encounter), getting all of them out of the way one after another.  This is a bit of a shame.

I found myself surprisingly engaged in the story and characters but occasionally got yanked out of that state of mind with the grindy nature of the game.  Still, I'm glad I played this.

This game is worth buying if you're into RPGs and are at a loss of the next one to play.

reviewText:
PROS:
- Very good game for the money.
- Old school
- Massive amounts of enemies.
- Levels scale well.
- Comedic storyline.
- Addicting
- Level perks to choose from every level (Increase HP or Stats? Learn a spell or passive ability?)

CONS:
- Dungeons are way too long, multi-path puzzle dungeons.
- Can only buy weapons/armor, cannot buy potions/1-Ups.
- Some bosses early on is difficult.
- A lot of grinding necessary.

FINAL THOUGHTS:
I beat this game in around 13 hours with a lot of grinding, I got it for 98 cents on sale so it was worth the money...even at normal price its worth the money.  The grinding was surprisingly fun(I listed it as a con because a majority of people dont like grinding), and the amount of spells leaves you constantly looking for better ways to defeat your enemies, although a lot of spells become obsolete, some spells you get early on can still be used at end-game for enemy ailments(such as Blind or Stun).  Overall its worth it, make sure you get the combo pack that includes Breath of Death VII.

reviewText:
This and Breath of Death VII are two games that demonstrate an absolutely simple but at the same time revolutionary concept for JRPGs and gaming in general that I think more big time companies and other indie developers should take up on while still making games of the calibur they do now.

In short, I speak of shortness, but not being cut off. A game that doesn't ramble, but tells its story and gives plenty of stuff to do along the way without feeling rushed. Cthulhu Saves the World does this within each of its campaigns but provides plenty of enjoyable replayability in its multiple game modes, unlockable content, simple on the surface but deep under the skin combat systems and absolutely -awesome- wit and charm.

And to think, this is a game about an Old God trying to regain the ability to destroy the world and he's the protagonist! Maddness :O

reviewText: Play as everyones favorite Lovecraftian god on a quest to presumably eat everything in this cheeky homage/parody (homarody?) of 16 bit era RPGs. Overworld gameplay is reminiscent of Final Fantasy 4+5 whereas the battle system is from first-person perspective, ala Dragon Quest and Earthbound. The game is pretty much set for the sake of speedily getting through battles rather than focus on cinematic 3D nonsense with overlong special moves and junk (I'm looking at you as if I were some disappointed yet still encouraging teacher, Final Fantasy 7), which is definitely a plus since the game's quirky humor and characters are quite enjoyable. One of the billion Zeboyd RPGs, alongside Breath of Death and the latter Penny Arcadeses.

reviewText: If your in for a short but intriguing indie adventure, that's what your looking for. The battle system may not be so deep, the tech tree may not be so branch-full": but c'mon you can unleash madness all over your foes
date: bind them in fear and kill them with just your presence (actually later on in the game may happen!). What else do you need?\n\nThe story: if you take it lightheartedly you'll laugh and enjoy it all the way
recommended: plus most of the referencies and quotes speak for the effort of the writers.\n\nThe commentaries (you need to switch them on at the beginning of the game) are short to read and help you feel closer to the concept of the game
hoursPlayed:
sharing the path with the developer's notes.

The monsters: awesome concept art and don't forget to read each and every monster description during the battle.

The leveling-up mechanic: a fork (2 choiches) at every level give you options to build your party; some of the techniques your party can learn really add flavour to the gameplay (Cthulhu's Tentacles or Paws's Nuke).

The music: epic
voteText: with some 90s flavour.\n\nRecommended to old RPG-lovers in for a break from too deep mechanics and to weird fiction addicts looking for a light and nice divertissement."

reviewText: Both Cthulhu Saves the World and Breath of Death VII are some of the most wonderful, funny, and self-referential odes to classic 8-bit gaming that exist today. Credit goes to Zeboyd games for revitalizing the classic formulas for today's audiences, while still keeping what made them special.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Basically the same as Breath of Death VII, but more... evil. You play the role of Cthulhu. Having been stripped of all his power, Cthulhu learns (due to the narrator's indiscretion) that the only way to regain his evil supremeness is to become a true hero.

I would recommend playing Breath of Death before playing this. It's still not a very complicated game, but BoD is a pretty good primer, while CStW introduces some more complex mechanics.

The game is good, the humor is great, and the story is standard.

Final grade: B-

This is a very old game, with all-new content. It's nice to have a couple of this game around for when you just wannat unwind with a nice, comfortable old adventure grind.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Overall I felt that Cthulhu Saves the World is a weaker game than Breath of Death VII. Zeboyd's first game was more of a genre parody of JRPGs, while Cthulhu feels like a Lovecraft parody that happens to take the form of a JRPG - and not a very strong parody at that. It's silly Lovecraft, and not a clever overturning of Lovecraft's themes and conventions (like Breath of Death was for JRPGs). But that doesn't mean it's not funny and enjoyable. The fast levelling and combat did a good job of keeping me engaged, and the game is that kind that's short in a good way, so that it doesn't overstay its welcome.\n\nFull review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2013/09/cthulhu-saves-world.html

reviewText: This game is as hilarious as its title makes it sound.  You're Cthulhu, the Dark One, and, through silliness, you must, as the title suggests, save the world. I would like to hear from an expert on Lovecraft just how well things in this story fit the mythos.  It comes with Breath of Death VII, made by the same guy, which is just as funny.  In that, you're a mute skeleton hero.

reviewText:
This is the best game you can get for under 5 euros. It's extremely addicting and a great retro-game with the retro feeling. Though what differs this from other older RPG of this kind is:

1. This game has a great sense of humor.
2. You can save whenever you want.
3. You can teleport to towns you've already been to.

If you choose to buy this you will have some great laughs and you get to experience a super-fun retro RPG with all the fun elements of an old-school with some fixes that makes it more enjoying.

100/100 turtles.

reviewText: This is probably one of my favourite games in my library.  Cthulhu Save the World is very well made.  Graphics are a throwback to SNES era graphics.  The sound is forgetable, but catchy and appropriate.  Gameplay is similar to other SNES generation turn-based RPGs.  In all aspects, Zeboyd Games showed massive improvements since Breath of Death.  The story is fun, well paced, and memorable.  Standard story mode takes around 7-10 hours to complete and you still have several bonus modes to keep you occupied afterwards.\n\nBottomline: Cthulhu Saves the World is a must-have for any fan of the RPG genre.

Cthulhu Saves The World is quite possibly the stupidest game I've ever enjoyed playing.


Cthulhu has arisen to destroy the world
column23: but has his powers sapped. And the only way to regain them is to become a true hero. And so
column24:
Cthulhu sets off on a quest to save the world in order to destroy the world.


You'll have to enlist the help of a colorful band of allies
column25: including an alien cat and a talking sword. Cthulhu even enlists some pretty female characters
column26:
which I'm 100% sure were put there purely in hopes of someone R34-ing it.


I mean
column27:
that's what I'd do if I made a game about Cthulhu.



If the premise of the game isn't goofy enough
column28: it's sure to drive the punchline home within the first few seconds of the game. Before you can even take control of Cthulhu
column29: the fourth wall is pretty much obliterated. And it stays that way for the entire game. Cthulhu and pals will pick fights with the narrator
column30: point out the glaring "RPG logic" plot holes in the story
column31:
and reference the fact that they're in a game multiple times.


Not that it's a problem by any means. It's actually the highlight of the game.


The writing and dialogue in the game is hilarious
column33: and sometimes even witty.\n\nEach enemy will have a short description when you get into a fight. Something like "Wizard - Fun at birthday parties" or "Ghost Knight - Totally not a palette swap". They can range from incredibly witty to stupidly nonsensical
column34:
but are entertaining nonetheless.


I found myself talking to every NPC
column36: and pretty much searching the entire game for anywhere that may contain more juicy bits of text. The writing is definitely strong
column37:
and anyone with a sense of humor and a love of retro RPG's will definitely be able to appreciate the subtle references and jokes.


Joke games can usually go either way though. If too much emphasis is on the humor to the point where the game is unpolished or unplayable
column38:
it won't get too far based on the humor alone. Laughing at a game and laughing with a game are too entirely different types of entertainment.


Lucky for Cthulhu though
column39:
we're laughing with him.


Cthulhu Saves The World has your standard retro RPG setup. Turn-based combat
column41: random encounters for experience and gold for leveling up and getting better equipment. All of that is there
column42:
with a few twists.





The biggest twist has to be that Cthulhu doesn't have amnesia. Or brightly colored hair. But his skin is green
column43:
though. That's close enough.



The battles seem to encourage the idea of speed. Of striking hard
column44:
and striking fast.

With tentacles.

Enemies will grow stronger each turn
column45: meaning if you're too slow they'll eventually double or even triple in strength. Enough to kill your entire party in a few hits. You have a similar feature though. A combo meter that will build up with every hit
column46:
which will boost damage on certain combo finisher moves.


Even the items in the game are short and to the point. In fact
column47: there's really only two. And only one of those you can freely use in battle. Unlike a standard RPG where you'd be weighed down with Phoenix Downs
column48: status recoveries for every possible ailment
column49:
and all sorts of stuff you need to stock up on but rarely ever use.


You'll have 1-ups to revive your entire party if you fall
column50:
and Potions to fully restore an ally. That's pretty much it.



There's a number of features like this to make the experience smoother and quicker. You can save anywhere
column51:
and your party heals all HP and a bit of MP after each battle.



But most importantly
column52: probably the best idea out of this whole game
column53:
is the random encounter limit.


Each dungeon will have a set amount of battles. Roughly 20-ish for most. But after you've defeated them all
column54: you're done. You can casually explore as much as you like after
column55: and nothing will pop up and attack you. The choice is still there if you'd like to fight; there's a button on the menu that will trigger battles for you if you'd still like to grind more. But at that point
column56:
you'd be pretty much as strong as you'd need to be anyway.



Like any retro RPG
column57: it does seem to drag on at times. It can get pretty repetitive and grindy towards the end
column58:
especially after you've read every funny monster description and just mash the button to kill things. But it's definitely a solid RPG game.



For those that find it to their liking
column59: they'll be pleased to find a number of bonus things to do after the game is over. Multiple bonus modes to play
column60: and collectibles to unlock.\n\nYour party members even have crude "skill trees" as they level up. And by that
column61: I mean "You can choose to make Cthulhu a physical attacker or a magical attacker". Not anything as fancy as modern RPG's
column62:
but it gives you a bit more to play with every playthrough I guess.


It even has a pretty nice soundtrack
column63:
like any RPG should.



Cthulhu Saves The World is a great RPG and definitely something to check out. Colorful
column65:
and full of tentacles.







That's how I like my women."

So much fun! Great for casual players and lovers of humor.

reviewText:
This is an odd title, to say the least.  It's a solid game...  But seems to exist less as a game than as a parody of a game.

Cthulhu Saves the World is very reminiscent of the old Final Fantasy games.  Similar gameplay mechanics.  Similar character and storyline tropes.  Except...  You aren't actually playing as a hero out to save the world from an ancient evil.  You're playing as an ancient evil out to destroy the world.

The graphics are delightfully nostalgic.  Simple 2D sprites that immediately brought me back to the old Dragon Quest and Final Fantasy games.

The combat mechanics, also, hearken back to those classic games.

But the humor is delightfully fresh.  Lots of fun being poked at the CRPG genre.  Lots of self-aware humor.

It's a simple, fun game.  And cheap.  But I'm not sure if it'd hold my attention long enough to actually play through to the end.

reviewText: Like Breath of Death, you can get this game for super, duper cheap and like Breath of Death, it's worth every penny.  This game has several play modes for crazy replayability, a polished combat system focusing on quick decisions, but also risk reward mechanics, such as making your enemies stronger but weakening their defense, and a story that is both humrous and endearing.  It's the Cthulhu mythos and all things lovecraftian made into a quirky Jrpg and the result is pretty amazing.  Also, this game has one of the best things in any Jrpg.  The ability to avoid random battles.  If you fight a certain number of battles in any dungeon, then you stop getting into random battles.  You can choose to grind and fight more, but this feature makes the game so much more enjoyable than your standard Jrpg.  Must play.

reviewText:
Fun throwback to ye olden days RPG, or JRPG if you prefer. The game is in the style of the old Final Fantasy games which for me does have some nostalgia value since I remember playing FF 4 or 5 on my old Gameboy Color.

But the game itself is pretty entertaining. The story is amusing, I've had a few good laughs throughout my playthrough so far. The aesthetic is fairly good if you like the 16 bit style. I've had a couple problems with the UI but nothing major after I got used to it, my biggest complaint is that the game doesn't seem to want to let you Alt-tab out of it.

One thing you DO NEED TO KNOW is that if you lose a fight and don't want to spend a 1-up to try again, hitting backspace to quit will force you to reload your last save file. So save frequently and if you're thinking about quiting out of a fight consider how long it's been since your last save. :P

The dungeons are maybe a bit too large and somes feel convoluted, I definitely got lost a time or two. And due to the nature of exploring through being constantly attacked with random encounters this can mean the game can drag on a little. Personally I've enjoyed the game enough this has not bothered me, but if you're expecting this to be a quick little experience you may find otherwise. So far I've played probably around 8 or 10 hours on Hard difficulty and I still haven't reached the ending.

Speaking of difficulty, I found the game a bit too easy on Normal so I had to stick it out through Hard even though at the start MP management is a pain (mana points). Now that's almost disappeared as a concern since all my characters have over 100 MP and some even over 300 and the spell costs didn't really grow in proportion, but I consider that a good thing. Some dungeons are still long enough that I'm starting to run out of MP near the end, for a couple I've even had to go back to town and come back to refill on MP. It can be a bit tedious but Normal difficulty just felt too easy. Though if you just want to blitz through the game just for the story, then going on Normal or Easy is probably the way to do so.

The character development in terms of combat is interesting because it genuinely does feel like it's possible to have your characters fill the role you wish them to, at least to a certain point. For example your first party member Umi at first seems like a great mage but I think she's actually a better fighter/support and should focus on Str which will really come into form when you pick up Thor's Call somewhere above lvl 20. As she levels you can try to push her down the mage tree but I honestly don't think she'll ever be as good as October. Similarly it's possible to try to make Cthulhu a mage, but I don't think he'd do all that well either, and for both characters I feel this is mostly due to a lack of spells. October gets the access to the full wizard toolkit, while Umi and Cthulhu can only really pick up the occasional spell. And unfortunately it seems once you make a level up choice there is no way to alter your choices, so later on you may regret spending points in one direction or another.
Generally most characters feel useful in some capacity or another, except for maybe Paws. He has extremely high Agility, can toggle the enemy group's insanity on or off, and that's about it? He just seems to be lacking any combat skills to make him effective and even when he gets a couple they don't really do enough damage. The insanity bit is interesting but I don't see a reason to bring him along when Dacre can support much better, both Umi and October are better Mages, and Umi, October, and Sharpe all do way more damage. He's a sort of Jack off All Trades, Master of None in that he can do a bit of just about everything, but all of it is kinda weak. I think he'd have been better if he had been more focused on something.

Overall I would say the combat is competent, which is fine since I think humor is meant to also be a large part of the attraction and in my opinion it works. And I do like the fact you can skip through all the combat text if you so desire, so combat only takes as long as you want it to. Though some of the harder fights did require me to pay attention.
The Insanity mechanic is pretty interesting in that you can get buffs from enemies being insane and it looks funny/cool, and I know the devs intended for it to be a double edged sword, but I tend to find the edge that cuts back at me is a bit too sharp. It's fun seeing October cast Void on an insane group and do 1400 dmg in aoe to a massive crowd, or seeing Cthulhu Dark Strike an insane enemy for like 3k dmg, but it's not so much fun when the enemies start throwing their insanity buffed nukes at you and party members start dropping like flies. All in all I've found it better to avoid turning most enemies insane and just mess around with it from time to time rather than trying to rely on it.

Steam says I have played 12 hours but it's really more like 8-10, but I still haven't finished the game or tried the extra game modes so I hope to be entertained even more by the mighty Cthulhu as he strives to be a true hero.

tl;dr version: A funny, quirky game in the style of oldschool RPGs like the early Final Fantasy titles. Not perfect but it's fun enough to kill a good few hours and has a generous amount of content at a generous price, so imo well worth effort.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
CStW certainly gives a bang for your buck; at a mere $3 when not on sale, I can easily recommend it for it's humor (and if you so desire - challenge). You play as Cthulhu, stripped of his dark powers by a mysterious foe. The only way to regain them? Perform great heroic deeds. So begins the misadventures of Cthulhu and his colorful band of misfits you pick up (or groupies as I took to calling them).

The game itself is not demanding on your hardware, as one might expect from a retro RPG.

The combat is fluid, simple, and rewards your choices - on higher difficulties it can be utterly unforgiving, reminiscent of much older games.

And as I’ve said, the game has a great sense of humor about itself. Personally, I found myself compelled to continue playing solely to see what the next joke may be.

Grade: B.

A solid game that will last you anywhere from 5 to 9 hours on the first campaign, with a few extras to boot. Humor and Combat are it's strong points; the plot is a parody more than anything.

reviewText:
Honestly, I would recommend this game on the music alone. The battle theme is great for setting the tone of the encounter and the town themes are quite varied. The music aside, this game really is quite funny without forcing humor. It plays on the already ridiculous concept well and just has fun with it.

It's nice to see the old style of RPG back but what makes it better is how quick the battles go, in terms of the action boxes. I'm not saying the battles are easy, oh god no. Enemies can hit like semi trucks and knock you flat before you realize what's happening. There are plenty of attacks/spells/combos/what-have-you to pick through so to make a play style that works and is personally appealing.

Things can get super tricky, though. The HP restore at the end of each battle is amazing but the lack of potions purchase can  really throw a wrench into the works. I see how the game could be too easy if you could purchase them considering how potions work but it's the last thing that matters when running out in the middle of a fight. The slow MP restore after every battle helps too but it means you have to be careful when using your favorite MP-using attacks. Thankfully, there's a MP restore/save point before every major boss battle so it's not like you'll go into a tough-as-nails battle completely unprepared for it.

I'm almost six hours in (up to Kingsport) but I'm loving this game to death. Can't wait to see where it goes.

reviewText:
You play Cthulhu on a quest to regain your eldritch powers. The only way to do this is to become a hero by traveling around the world map, visiting fantasy towns named after Mythos locations, and laying the smackdown on your Great Old One brethren. Along the way you pick up several party members (one of whom seems to represent some kind of cameo; the game certainly seemed to expect me to recognize her).

The combat is full-on Dragon Quest. The enemies line up in front of you and you ATTACK / DEFEND / MAGIC / ITEM etc. The combat system is tweaked to be more user-friendly than similar games from the 1980s, and there are other conveniences (like being able to save anywhere) that eliminate most of the frustration factor.

The only downside is that this DOES make the game pretty easy. Completing it unlocks another mode called Cthulhu's Angels, where the title character stays on the sidelines but you start with three party members. I didn't play that far in this mode, but it seems significantly more difficult (and, bless, features its own separate story traversing the same locations).

reviewText: Well worth the price even more so considering that it includes Breath of Death VII. Very reminicent of classic Final Fantasy games graphicaly but with far faster gameplay. Very funny as well. One intersting mechanic to note is that you only have to fight a set number of enemies in a given location. So when you fight x amount of battles you don't have to fight anymore enemies. But if you want or feel you need to grind you can open the menu and chose fight to fight more battles. Overall it is a fun time that lasts a good 8 hrs on normal with more modes unlocked as soon as you beat the main game.

I love this game.
If you like pixal art and RPG-maker look game, try it.
Chutlu saves the world is a RPG turn per turn with a increasing difficulty each turn.
It's a pretty difficult in normal mode and you need tou farm and level up a bit to beat the final boss.

There is tons of humor and references, I enjoyed clicking on every library, shelf and wardobe just to see what the developper had written.

The main quest is simple and linear but when you play this anti-RPG that make fun of the genre, you don't really care.
You just want to help chtulhu and his crazy team to saves the world (and argue with the narator)

reviewText:
Madness and Glory to the great Cthulhu! Cthulhu Saves The World is an excellent, quiet well designed game that is a definite throwback to 'old-school' RPGs while being quite accessible to new players. I certainly enjoyed it, and if you can get in the double pack alongside Breath of Death VII it's a steal. Only problem I found was that the dungeons were far too long and confusing, and you might be put off in trying to complete some of them. Still, the particular mechanic of having a limited amount of mandatory dungeon battles is practically a(n old)godsend as it allows gamers of different types to approach dungeons how they wish, to a certain extent. If you can take your time with the game, it will reward you. The director's commentary is always a nice treat as well.

Pros: Solid Humor, references to RPGs and Lovecraft aplenty, large world to explore, good variety of foes
Cons: Long, somewhat steep difficulty, dungeon design confusingly, MADDENINGLY tedious.

Overall: 4/5

reviewText:
A very charming homage to the RPG genre and the cthulhu mythos, complete with witty humor/dialogue, diverse cast of playable characters, tons of land to explore, bosses and enemies to conquer, mutiple gameplay strategies to implement on fights and a amazing soundtrack, you got yourself a very, very nice game here at 2.99 USD.

Just to give you an idea on the gameplay, if you've been getting your ♥♥♥ kicked by enemies and bosses, you actually DON'T have to go on a grind fest or a tedious side quest to find hidden equipment just to beat him/them, unlike many other RPG's. With the combo system along with the insanity and unite mechanics and a huge variety of characters to pull different combinations of moves, I found that just simply changing tactics and experimenting what works and what doesn't, is much better than tedious grinding most RPG's pit you up with.

I've beaten the final boss on level 36 in insanity mode, the hardest difficulty, on my first real playthrough and believe me when I say insanity mode is hard, the hours I have don't lie. If that isn't a testament to how the gameplay is set from other traditional RPG's, I don't know what else will convince you.


If you're new to RPG's and/or just want something different to the mix, you owe it to yourself to pick this game up.
